author: AOL Staff
title: Pro-life leader anticipates major victories despite recent ballot initiatives expanding abortion access
text: Pro-life leader anticipates major victories despite recent ballot initiatives expanding abortion access For a prominent pro-life group, recent setbacks at the ballot box have not tampered spirits for the future of the movement to create a culture that protects unborn life in the womb. The March for Life â€” the organization and the annual event that attracts tens of thousands of people (at least) from across the country each January â€” has grown significantly in the 50 years since the first march in 1974. Activists assembled on the first anniversary of the Supreme Court's 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade, which effectively made [abortion legal](https://www.foxnews.com/category/politics/judiciary/supreme-court) in every state across the country. Since then, the march always had Roe as its chief point of protest, but in the year and a half since the [Supreme Court overturned](https://www.foxnews.com/category/politics/judiciary/supreme-court) Roe's precedent in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health, the energy surrounding the march has not waned. "The march for life was born in a moment after Roe was overturned, and there was a lot of confusion about choosing life, and the unborn child," March for Life President Jeanne Mancini told Fox News Digital in an interview. "We think this particular moment calls for these marches, and that the pro-life grassroots needs strengthening and even a little direction right now. That's where we see the state march program as being so critically important." [FORMER TRUMP ADVISER KELLYANNE CONWAY LEADS CHARGE TO OVERHAUL GOP ABORTION STRATEGY, END DEMS' 2024 ADVANTAGE](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/kellyanne-conway-leads-charge-overhaul-gop-abortion-strategy-end-democrat-2024-advantage) In the past five years, the March for Life has expanded to the state level, hosting annual rallies in cities across the country organized by state chapters of the national organization. The state-level expansion is moving fast. In 2018, March for Life Virginia held an inaugural march. In 2023, eight states held marches, and next year March for Life will be in 17 states, and Mancini has plans to be in every state in the union in the next six years or so. Following the Dobbs decision in June 2022, pro-life leaders and conservative politicians have sought to redirect activism to state-level political battles and focus on creating a "culture of life." March for Life's goal, Mancini said, is to create a world where "abortion is unthinkable." That effort is as much about helping women with unexpected pregnancies as it is about changing laws around abortion. "There's so much confusion about what it means to be a woman, and frankly, what it means to be pro-life. The heart of pro-life is supporting women and wanting what's best for them," Mancini said. The political fight over abortion does not appear to be going away, and pro-life leaders are far from giving up on pushing for state or national pro-life legislation. However, pro-life causes have had a series of setbacks in statewide ballot initiatives in the past two elections. Most recently, Ohio voted to enshrine a right to access abortion into its state constitution in November. "With the ballot initiatives, we're learning a lot," Mancini said. "As we're moving and changing culture, we're going to have lessons along the way." [PRO-LIFE GROUP ADDRESSES WHAT WENT WRONG IN OHIO ABORTION VOTE, HOW TO RESPOND IN 2024](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/pro-life-group-what-went-wrong-ohio-abortion-vote-how-to-respond-2024) As many pro-life leaders have pointed out, Mancini noted that public opinion surveys show most Americans are not in favor of completely unrestricted abortion. "For at least 12 years strong, 7 out of 10 Americans would limit abortion at most to the first three months of pregnancy. And that's not our national law," Mancini said. "Some states do enact protective laws of life prior to that moment, which is wonderful, but our national law is not in line with most of Europe." The theme of the 2024 March for Life is "with every woman, for every child." It aims to address the confusion and show that being pro-life is not only about political fights without regard to the difficulties of an unplanned pregnancy. "We see two patients when someone is facing an unexpected pregnancy, and we want both of those patients to fully flourish." The Charlotte Lozier Institute released a report earlier in December about the impact nearly 3,000 pro-life [pregnancy centers](https://www.foxnews.com/media/pro-life-groups-hammer-twisted-attempt-democratic-ags-hinder-pregnancy-centers-from-helping-women) across the nation have had serving women. The [report showed](https://lozierinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/Pregnancy-Center-Update_2022.pdf) that in 2022 alone, the network of mostly locally-run pregnancy centers provided nearly 800,000 new client consultations, 700,000 pregnancy tests, half a million ultrasounds, and hundreds of thousands of STI tests, parenting classes and sexual risk avoidance education. Pregnancy centers also provided "after-abortion support" to 20,000 clients. The centers also delivered $358 million worth of material support for new mothers, including cribs, strollers, diapers, baby formula and car seats, the report said. Mancini said there was a distinction between advocacy for abortion access, and the pro-life movement. Abortion access tends to prey on women's fears, implying that those carrying an unplanned pregnancy are not capable of bearing or raising children, Mancini said. "The pro-life movement is the opposite," Mancini said. "We want to encourage and support women, come alongside them and strengthen them; and tell them 'you can do this. You have what it takes to do this. This is going to be hard, but it will be beautiful, and we will be here with you.'" Original article source: [Pro-life leader anticipates major victories despite recent ballot initiatives expanding abortion access](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/pro-life-leader-anticipates-major-victories-despite-recent-ballot-initiatives-expanding-abortion-access)

author: Jonah Chester jchester@postandcourier.com
title: 2024 ranks among Charleston's worst years for tidal flooding | Rising Waters | postandcourier.com
text:
By Jonah Chester jchester@postandcourier.com Jonah Chester
Jonah Chester covers flooding, sea level rise and climate change for the Post and Courier's Rising Waters Lab.
Author email Jan 3, 2025 7 mins ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Buy Now Kids run across Hagood Avenue during a king tide Sept. 20, 2024, in Charleston as high tide reaches its peak. Tide levels at the Charleston Harbor Tide Gauge reached 7.74 feet, signifying a "moderate" flood stage. Charleston experienced about 11 such floods in 2024.
File/Andrew Whitaker/Staff Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Charleston Harbor hit a flood stage 54 times in 2024. By the numbers, it was the calmest year for flooding in the Holy City since 2021. But it was one of the most active years since record-keeping began 100 years ago.
Specifically, 2024 took home seventh place on the National Weather Service's Coastal Flood Events Database .
As ocean levels near Charleston have risen about a foot over the past century, the number of tidal floods (also called "sunny day floods") has increased. Charleston experienced more tidal floods last year than it did in the entire period from late 1921 to 1958.
Donate to our Investigative Fund to support journalism like this Our public service and investigative reporting is among the most important work we do. It's also the most expensive reporting we do. We can't do it without your support.
Donate Now Water levels are likely to rise another foot-plus over the next 25 years, and city leaders point to the steady uptick in flooding as one of Charleston's greatest existential threats. As ocean levels rise, the frequency and severity of those tidal floods will increase. By 2050, Charleston could experience as many as 170 flood events per year, or about one every other day, according to Charleston's recently released Water Plan.
The harbor is considered in "flood stage" whenever it hits 7 feet or higher. Those stages are broken into three categories.
"Minor" begins at 7 feet, and it's the most frequent. These are typically nuisance floods that create large puddles, make the commute to and from work a bit tricky and may result in some light hydroplaning. "Moderate" begins at 7.5 feet, and at that point roads start closing down, lower-lying areas are inundated and residents can count on migraine-inducing traffic jams. "Major" floods occur at 8 feet or higher. Those are the washouts that swamp downtown, and essentially shut down the peninsula.
"Over 71 percent of all major tidal floods have occurred in the last nine years," Jared Bramblett, a senior water resources engineer at Moffatt & Nichol and one of the Water Plan's creators, said at a City Council meeting on the Water Plan in August.
Buy Now A truck moves through floodwaters in the intersection of Fishburne Street and Hagood Avenue during a king tide Sept. 20, 2024, in Charleston. The area is one of the lowest-lying in the city, and floods regularly.
File/Andrew Whitaker/Staff Charleston experienced three of those major floods last year. According to Charleston's Water Plan, the city could see nearly 30 such washouts annually by 2050 â€” or one roughly every two weeks.

author: Qatar Tribune
title: Miracle Nation wins inaugural Distaff Cup - Read Qatar Tribune on the go for unrivalled news coverage
text:
Tribune News Network
Doha
The Yousuf Mubarak YA Al Kuwari-owned Miracle Nation won the inaugural Distaff Cup for trainer Hamad Al Jehani at the Al Uqda Racecourse on Thursday.
The three-year-old filly was given a brilliant ride by Faleh Bughanaim as she edged out Al Rufaa Racingâ€™s Cathy Come Home in the dayâ€™s feature, the 1400m Conditions for Thoroughbred Fillies and Mares.
The filly did well to thwart the spirited bid of the Gassim Ghazali-trained three-year-old ridden by Szczepan Mazur to win by a neck. Abdulatif Hussain MZ Al Emadi owned and Bader Al Balushi-trained Kaliysta was ridden by Al Moatasem Al Balushi to finish third.
Jockey Szczepan Mazur guided Al Jeryan Studâ€™s AJS Anayid to win the 1400m Purebred Arabian Handicap (65-85) for three-year-old race.
In the meeting opener, Toufik in the silks of Wathnan Racing was ridden by Alberto Sanna to 1400m Local Purebred Arabian Maiden Plate race for three-six-year-olds.
Abdulaziz Jassim Al Boenain, Al Uqda Complex Manager, presented the trophies to the winners.
 Copy 29/12/2023 10

text:
Con un firme compromiso hacia el bienestar social y ambiental, PPG Comex, a travÃ©s de su programa "Comex por un MÃ©xico Bien Hecho", estÃ¡ llevando a cabo una expansiÃ³n significativa en su labor de impacto social. Entre los Estados en los que se han rehabilitado espacios se encuentran: Estado de MÃ©xico, Guanajuato, QuerÃ©taro, Veracruz, MichoacÃ¡n, Puebla, Jalisco, Oaxaca, Nuevo LeÃ³n y Quintana Roo.
Este esfuerzo no solo ampliarÃ¡ el alcance del programa, sino que tambiÃ©n permitirÃ¡ que mÃ¡s comunidades vulnerables se beneficien de la revitalizaciÃ³n de sus entornos. Comex continÃºa promoviendo el fortalecimiento del tejido social, la equidad de gÃ©nero, el cuidado del medio ambiente y la dignificaciÃ³n de espacios pÃºblicos. La compaÃ±Ã­a sigue apostando por el color, el arte y la participaciÃ³n ciudadana como motores de transformaciÃ³n, impactando positivamente en la vida de millones de personas y contribuyendo al desarrollo sostenible del paÃ­s.
Publicidad
Comex pinta un futuro mejor
Gracias a su enfoque integral y metodolÃ³gico, Comex por un MÃ©xico Bien Hecho no solo embellece y protege los espacios pÃºblicos, sino que tambiÃ©n genera un impacto positivo y tangible en la vida de millones de personas. Con una red de 600 concesionarios y alianzas estratÃ©gicas, como la establecida con Blue Women Pink Men, el programa ha rehabilitado 119 canchas y continÃºa expandiendo su alcance para mejorar la calidad de vida en comunidades vulnerables.
La metodologÃ­a de Comex por un MÃ©xico Bien Hecho incorpora la colaboraciÃ³n de expertos en antropologÃ­a, psicologÃ­a y sociologÃ­a para garantizar un impacto real y medible. Las evaluaciones realizadas han demostrado mejoras significativas, como un aumento del 25% en la frecuencia de visitas a las canchas deportivas y un incremento del 15% en la participaciÃ³n de niÃ±as en actividades deportivas. La iniciativa tambiÃ©n ha logrado fortalecer el sentido de seguridad en las comunidades, con un 38% de los adultos afirmando que las intervenciones han mejorado su entorno.

author: Von Oliver Schmale, dpa
title: Tarifeinigung fÃ¼r DÃ¶nerfabrik Birtat
text:
Arbeitskampf
Tarifeinigung fÃ¼r DÃ¶nerfabrik Birtat
Murr (dpa)
Die schwÃ¤bische DÃ¶nerfabrik Birtat ist einer der fÃ¼hrenden Hersteller von DÃ¶nerspieÃŸen. Die Mitarbeiter kÃ¤mpfen fÃ¼r einen Tarifvertrag und bessere Bezahlung. Nun freuen sie sich Ã¼ber die Einigung.
Die BeschÃ¤ftigten beim DÃ¶nerspieÃŸ-Hersteller Birtat zerkleinern Fleisch, marinieren und stecken es dann auf die SpieÃŸe - ein Knochenjob. FÃ¼r sie gilt kÃ¼nftig nach Gewerkschaftsangaben der erste Tarifvertrag in der DÃ¶nerfleischindustrie. In ihm wurde der Einstiegslohn auf 2.600 Euro festgelegt, wie die Gewerkschaft Nahrung-Genuss-GaststÃ¤tten (NGG) und das Unternehmen Meat World SE (Birtat) in Murr bei Ludwigsburg gemeinsam mitteilten. FÃ¼r Betriebsratschef Muzayfe Doganer ist mit dem Haustarifvertrag Â«ein TraumÂ» wahr geworden. Â«Ich wollte weinen.Â» Er sei stolz auf die rund 120 Mitarbeiter. Es sei ein Ergebnis, das fÃ¼r beide Seiten gut sei.
Ferner sei eine Anhebung der Entgelte in zwei Stufen im Gesamtumfang von bis zu 17 Prozent in der Spitze bei einer Laufzeit bis Ende 2026 vereinbart worden, wie beide Seiten mitteilten.
Die Gewerkschaft NGG hatte eine ErhÃ¶hung der Entgelte um monatlich 375 Euro und einen Tarifvertrag gefordert. Die BeschÃ¤ftigten legten ihre Arbeit an elf unterschiedlichen Tagen zeitweise nieder.
NGG-VerhandlungsfÃ¼hrerin Magdalena KrÃ¼ger sagte, dieser Tarifabschluss sei ein historisches Ergebnis in der DÃ¶nerfleischbranche und ein Erfolg der BeschÃ¤ftigten.
Unternehmenssprecher Cihan Karaman sagte laut der gemeinsamen Mitteilung: Â«Wir sind Ã¼berzeugt, dass dieser Vertrag nicht nur Planungssicherheit schafft, sondern auch das Vertrauen und die Zusammenarbeit zwischen Unternehmen und BeschÃ¤ftigten stÃ¤rkt.Â» Der Vertrag ist ein Haustarifvertrag, weil er zwischen der Gewerkschaft und dem Unternehmen abgeschlossen worden ist.
Verband: 400 DÃ¶nerhersteller in Deutschland
Die Tarifauseinandersetzung wurde in den vergangenen Wochen mit harten Bandagen gefÃ¼hrt. Beide Seiten mussten ZugestÃ¤ndnisse machen. In der zweiten Urabstimmung votierten rund 90 Prozent der befragten NGG-Mitglieder fÃ¼r die Annahme des Tarifvertrags.
Die Tarifparteien verpflichten sich zudem, nun Ã¼ber einen Tarifvertrag zur Eingruppierung sowie einen Manteltarifvertrag zu verhandeln. Die Gewerkschaft hofft, dass sie kÃ¼nftig gleichfalls bei anderen Unternehmen der Branche tarifvertragliche Regelungen durchsetzen kann. DGB-Landeschef Kai Burmeister sagte, der Tarifabschluss bei Birtat sei ein toller und hart erkÃ¤mpfter Erfolg fÃ¼r die BeschÃ¤ftigten und die NGG. Birtat gehÃ¶rt zur Meat World SE, nach NGG-Angaben der grÃ¶ÃŸte Hersteller von DÃ¶nerspieÃŸen in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg - und einer der fÃ¼hrenden Anbieter in Deutschland. In der Fabrik stecken die Mitarbeiterinnen und Mitarbeiter Fleisch vom Kalb, HÃ¤hnchen oder Rind auf SpieÃŸe - und geben dem Ganzen die traditionelle Form. Die SpieÃŸe werden dann schockgefrostet und ausgeliefert.
Birtat versorgt nach eigenen Angaben Tausende Imbisse und erreicht mehr als 13 Millionen Konsumentinnen und Konsumenten monatlich. Â«Unsere Produkte kann man fast in jeder groÃŸen Stadt in Europa verkostenÂ», sagte ein Firmensprecher kÃ¼rzlich. Man sei MarktfÃ¼hrer. Meat World machte demnach zuletzt einen Jahresumsatz von ungefÃ¤hr 200 Millionen Euro. Nach Angaben des Verbands der DÃ¶nerproduzenten gibt es etwa 400 DÃ¶nerhersteller hierzulande.

author: Morning Call Staff
title: Tri-County area gets a northern lights show. See photos and share your pics â€“ The Mercury
text:
Residents across region are reporting seeing the northern lights Thursday night.
The aurora borealis was expected to be visible over much of the northern half of the country following a solar storm, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The National Weather Service in Mount Holly, New Jersey, had said skies would be clear over our region.
The best viewing conditions were expected between 8 p.m. and midnight, according to the weather service. Those who wish to see the northern lights will need to have an unobstructed view facing north or overhead, away from light pollution.
The northern lights were visible in the area in August as well.
Just after 7 p.m., the weather serviceâ€™s Mount Holly office shared a photo on X showing the aurora borealis in the sky from their office .
